## Why This Is Asked

Tests ability to design a per-tenant provenance flow, integrate image signing and SBOMs, and apply admission controls with policy-as-code. It also checks practical knowledge of Gatekeeper/OPA integration, namespace-scoped policies, and minimal test workflows.

## Key Concepts

- Cosign signing with tenant-specific keys
- SPDX SBOM attachment and verification
- Gatekeeper ConstraintTemplate and Constraint
- Per-tenant policy in a ConfigMap
- Minimal manifests and kubectl validation in a single namespace

## Code Example

```yaml
# ConstraintTemplate (yaml)
apiVersion: templates.gatekeeper.sh/v1beta1
kind: ConstraintTemplate
metadata:
  name: k8simageprovenance
spec:
  crd:
    spec:
      names:
        kind: K8sImageProvenance
  targets:
  - target: admission.k8s.gatekeeper.sh
    rego: |
      package k8simageprovenance
      violation[{"msg": msg}] {
        input.review.kind.kind == "Deployment"
        some c in input.review.object.spec.template.spec.containers
        not startswith(c.image, "ghcr.io/")
        msg := "image provenance missing or not tenant-approved"
      }
```

```yaml
# Constraint (yaml)
apiVersion: constraints.gatekeeper.sh/v1beta1
kind: K8sImageProvenance
metadata:
  name: per-tenant-provenance
spec:
  enforcementAction: deny
  parameters:
    allowedTenant: "tenant-a"
```

```yaml
# Compliant Deployment (yaml)
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: tenant-a-gateway
  namespace: tenant-a
spec:
  replicas: 1
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: gateway
    spec:
      containers:
      - name: gateway
        image: ghcr.io/tenant-a/gateway:v1.0.0
```

```yaml
# Noncompliant Deployment (yaml)
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: tenant-a-gateway-bad
  namespace: tenant-a
spec:
  replicas: 1
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: gateway
    spec:
      containers:
      - name: gateway
        image: unsigned/gateway:latest
```

```bash
# Kubectl steps (one namespace first)
kubectl create ns tenant-a
# 1) Register constraint template and constraint
kubectl apply -f k8simageprovenance_template.yaml
kubectl apply -f k8simageprovenance_constraint.yaml
# 2) Sign and SBOM-attach a valid image (tenant-a key)
cosign sign --key cosign-tenant-a.key ghcr.io/tenant-a/gateway:v1.0.0
```

questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked
This question evaluates your ability to design end-to-end provenance controls for CNF environments, specifically addressing how key rotation impacts SBOM generation and policy enforcement in multi-tenant Kubernetes clusters.

- Cosign image signing with KMS-backed keys
- SPDX SBOM generation and attestation workflows
- Kyverno policy enforcement for signature and SBOM validation
- Key rotation impact on image provenance chains
- Namespace-scoped testing strategies and rollback procedures

## Code Example
```bash
# Sign image with KMS-backed key
cosign sign --key kms://mykms/path/to/key \
  --attachment sbom \
  registry.example.com/cnf:latest

# Generate and attach SBOM
syft registry.example.com/cnf:latest \
  -o spdx-json > sbom.spdx

cosign attest --key kms://mykms/path/to/key \
  --type spdx --predicate sbom.spdx \
  registry.example.com/cnf:latest
```

## Implementation Strategy
Deploy this solution progressively: start with image signing, add SBOM generation, implement Kyverno policies, then automate the key rotation workflow. Test in isolated namespaces before cluster-wide deployment.
